query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 «Poscia che Costantin l’aquila volse 2 contr’ al corso del ciel, ch’ella seguio 3 dietro a l’antico che Lavina tolse,
4 cento e cent’ anni e più l’uccel di Dio 5 ne lo stremo d’Europa si ritenne, 6 vicino a’ monti de’ quai prima uscìo;
7 e sotto l’ombra de le sacre penne 8 governò ’l mondo lì di mano in mano, 9 e, sì cangiando, in su la mia pervenne.

Please translate each line literally into English.
10 Cesare fui e son Iustinïano, 11 che, per voler del primo amor ch’i’ sento, 12 d’entro le leggi trassi il troppo e ’l vano.
query.result: 10 I was Caesar and I am Justinian, 11 who, for the desire of the first love that I feel, 12 from within the laws I drew the excess and the vain.

13 And before that I to the work was attentive, 14 a nature in Christ to be, no longer, 15 I believed, and of such faith was content;
16 but the blessed Agapitus, who was 17 supreme shepherd, to the sincere faith 18 directed me with his words.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
19 Io li credetti; e ciò che ’n sua fede era, 20 vegg’ io or chiaro sì, come tu vedi 21 ogni contradizione e falsa e vera.
query.result: 19 I believed them; and that which in his faith was, 20 now I see clearly so, as you see, 21 every contradiction both false and true.

22 Soon as with the Church I moved my feet, 23 to God, for grace, it pleased to inspire me 24 the lofty work, and all in him I gave myself;
25 and to my Belzar I commended the arms, 26 to whom the right hand of heaven was so joined, 27 that sign was that I should rest.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
28 Or qui a la question prima s’appunta 29 la mia risposta; ma sua condizione 30 mi stringe a seguitare alcuna giunta,
31 perché tu veggi con quanta ragione 32 si move contr’ al sacrosanto segno 33 e chi ’l s’appropria e chi a lui s’oppone.
query.result:
28 Or here to the first question it attaches 29 my answer; but its condition 30 compels me to follow some joining,
31 because you may see with how much reason 32 it moves against the most holy sign 33 and who appropriates it and who opposes it.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Vedi quanta virtù l’ha fatto degno 35 di reverenza; e cominciò da l’ora 36 che Pallante morì per darli regno.
query.result: 34 See how much virtue has made him worthy 35 of reverence; and it began from the hour 36 that Pallante died to give him the kingdom.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 Tu sai ch’el fece in Alba sua dimora 38 per trecento anni e oltre, infino al fine 39 che i tre a’ tre pugnar per lui ancora.
query.result: 37 You know that he made in Alba his dwelling 38 for three hundred years and beyond, up to the end 39 that the three to the three strive for him still

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 E sai ch’el fé dal mal de le Sabine 41 al dolor di Lucrezia in sette regi, 42 vincendo intorno le genti vicine.
query.result: 40 And you know that he did from the ill of the Sabines 41 to the pain of Lucrezia in seven reigns, 42 conquering around the nearby peoples

43 You know what he did, carried by the eminent 44 Romans encounter with Brenno, encounter with Pirro, 45 encounter with the other princes and colleges;
46 whereby Torquato and Quinzio, who from the cirro 47 neglected was named, the Deci and the Fabi 48 had the fame that willingly mirror.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Esso atterrò l’orgoglio de li Aràbi 50 che di retro ad Anibale passaro 51 l’alpestre rocce, Po, di che tu labi.
query.result: 49 It brought down the pride of the Arabs 50 that from behind to Hannibal passed 51 the alpine rocks, well, of which you lick

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 Sott’ esso giovanetti trïunfaro 53 Scipïone e Pompeo; e a quel colle 54 sotto ’l qual tu nascesti parve amaro.
query.result: 52 Under it the youngsters triumphed 53 Scipio and Pompey; and to that hill 54 under which you were born seemed bitter

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 Poi, presso al tempo che tutto ’l ciel volle 56 redur lo mondo a suo modo sereno, 57 Cesare per voler di Roma il tolle.
query.result: 55 Then, near the time that all the sky wanted 56 to bring back the world to its serene way, 57 Caesar, for the desire of Rome, takes

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
58 E quel che fé da Varo infino a Reno, 59 Isara vide ed Era e vide Senna 60 e ogne valle onde Rodano è pieno.
query.result: 58 And that which he did from Varo up to the Rhine, 59 Isara saw and Era and saw Senna 60 and every valley where Rhône is full.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
61 Quel che fé poi ch’elli uscì di Ravenna 62 e saltò Rubicon, fu di tal volo, 63 che nol seguiteria lingua né penna.
query.result: 61 That which he did then that he left Ravenna 62 and he leapt the Rubicon, it was of such flight, 63 that neither tongue nor pen would follow it

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Inver’ la Spagna rivolse lo stuolo, 65 poi ver’ Durazzo, e Farsalia percosse 66 sì ch’al Nil caldo si sentì del duolo.
query.result: 64 Inver’ the Spain turned the crowd, 65 then towards Durazzo, and Farsalia struck, 66 so that to the hot Nile was felt the sorrow.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
67 Antandro e Simeonta, onde si mosse, 68 rivide e là dov’ Ettore si cuba; 69 e mal per Tolomeo poscia si scosse.

Please translate each line literally into English.
70 Da indi scese folgorando a Iuba; 71 onde si volse nel vostro occidente, 72 ove sentia la pompeana tuba.

Please translate each line literally into English.
73 Di quel che fé col baiulo seguente, 74 Bruto con Cassio ne l’inferno latra, 75 e Modena e Perugia fu dolente.
query.result: 73 Of that which he did with the following bellow, 74 Bruto with Cassio in hell barks, 75 and Modena and Perugia was sorrowful.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Piangene ancor la trista Cleopatra, 77 che, fuggendoli innanzi, dal colubro 78 la morte prese subitana e atra.
query.result: 76 The sad Cleopatra still weeps for them, 77 who, fleeing them ahead, from the serpent 78 death took [her] sudden and dark.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
79 Con costui corse infino al lito rubro; 80 con costui puose il mondo in tanta pace, 81 che fu serrato a Giano il suo delubro.

Please translate each line literally into English.
82 Ma ciò che ’l segno che parlar mi face 83 fatto avea prima e poi era fatturo 84 per lo regno mortal ch’a lui soggiace,
85 diventa in apparenza poco e scuro, 86 se in mano al terzo Cesare si mira 87 con occhio chiaro e con affetto puro;
88 ché la viva giustizia che mi spira, 89 li concedette, in mano a quel ch’i’ dico, 90 gloria di far vendetta a la sua ira.

Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Or qui t’ammira in ciò ch’io ti replìco: 92 poscia con Tito a far vendetta corse 93 de la vendetta del peccato antico.
query.result: 91 Now here admires you in what I replenish to you: 92 afterwards with Titus ran to take revenge, 93 of the revenge of the ancient sin.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 E quando il dente longobardo morse 95 la Santa Chiesa, sotto le sue ali 96 Carlo Magno, vincendo, la soccorse.
query.result: 94 And when the Longobard tooth bit 95 the Holy Church, under its wings 96 Charlemagne, conquering, aided it

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Omai puoi giudicar di quei cotali 98 ch’io accusai di sopra e di lor falli, 99 che son cagion di tutti vostri mali.
query.result: 97 Now you can judge of those such 98 that I accused above and of their faults, 99 which are cause of all your evils.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 L’uno al pubblico segno i gigli gialli 101 oppone, e l’altro appropria quello a parte, 102 sì ch’è forte a veder chi più si falli.
query.result: 100 One opposes the yellow lilies to the public sign 101 and the other appropriates that one apart 102 so that it is strong to see who more fails

103 The Ghibellines do, they do their art 104 under another sign, because badly follows that 105 always he who justice and he separates;
106 and does not overthrow this new Charles 107 with his Guelphs, but fears of the claws 108 that to the highest lion draws the veil.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Molte fïate già pianser li figli 110 per la colpa del padre, e non si creda 111 che Dio trasmuti l’armi per suoi gigli!
112 Questa picciola stella si correda 113 d’i buoni spirti che son stati attivi 114 perché onore e fama li succeda:
115 e quando li disiri poggian quivi, 116 sì disvïando, pur convien che i raggi 117 del vero amore in sù poggin men vivi.
query.result:
109 Many fates already wept the children 110 for the fault of the father, and let not be believed 111 that God transmute the arms for his lilies!
112 This little star is accompanied 113 by the good spirits that have been active 114 so that honor and fame may succeed them:
115 and when the desires rest there, 116 so wandering, yet it is fitting that the rays 117 of true love upward rest less alive.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 Ma nel commensurar d’i nostri gaggi 119 col merto è parte di nostra letizia, 120 perché non li vedem minor né maggi.
query.result: 118 But in the commensuring of our gaggi 119 with merit is part of our joy, 120 because we do not see them smaller nor greater.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Quindi addolcisce la viva giustizia 122 in noi l’affetto sì, che non si puote 123 torcer già mai ad alcuna nequizia.
query.result: 121 Therefore sweetens the living justice 122 in us the affection so, that it cannot 123 twist ever again to any wickedness

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
124 Diverse voci fanno dolci note; 125 così diversi scanni in nostra vita 126 rendon dolce armonia tra queste rote.

Please translate each line literally into English.
127 E dentro a la presente margarita 128 luce la luce di Romeo, di cui 129 fu l’ovra grande e bella mal gradita.
query.result: 127 And inside the present daisy 128 light the light of Romeo, of whom 129 was the work great and beautiful ill‑liked

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Ma i Provenzai che fecer contra lui 131 non hanno riso; e però mal cammina 132 qual si fa danno del ben fare altrui.
query.result: 130 But the Provençals who did against him 131 have not laughed; and therefore walks badly 132 as one makes damage of the good doing of others

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Quattro figlie ebbe, e ciascuna reina, 134 Ramondo Beringhiere, e ciò li fece 135 Romeo, persona umìle e peregrina.
query.result: 133 Four daughters he had, and each one a queen, 134 Ramondo Beringhiere, and that made them 135 Romeo, humble and pilgrim person.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
136 E poi il mosser le parole biece 137 a dimandar ragione a questo giusto, 138 che li assegnò sette e cinque per diece,
139 indi partissi povero e vetusto; 140 e se ’l mondo sapesse il cor ch’elli ebbe 141 mendicando sua vita a frusto a frusto,
142 assai lo loda, e più lo loderebbe».
query.result:
136 And then he/she moved the bitter words 137 to ask reason of this just one, 138 who assigned them seven and five for ten,
139 then I left poor and ancient; 140 and if the world knew the heart that he had 141 begging his life to frusto to frusto,
142 much praises him, and would praise him more».
